newsitem.title: USA: U.S. stocks sharply lower at midday.
newsitem.headline: U.S. stocks sharply lower at midday.

text.p: The Dow Industrials were down more than 50 points at midday unsettled by a multitude of worries that included the possibility of a Democratic sweep in Congress and a market which has run very far very fast recently.
The Industrials were down 60 points, or 1.09 percent, at 5995, triggering the New York Stock Exchange's automatic curbs on index-arbitrage trades at 1147 EDT/1537 GMT.
"What we are seeing is a discounting process ahead of the election in November," said Joseph Barthel, chief investment strategist at Fahnestock & Co.
Big Board decliners led advancing issues by more than two to one on volume of about 195 million shares.
The Nasdaq Composite Index, which enjoyed a brief spell in positive territory this morning, was down five points, or 0.37 percent, at 1215.
U.S. Treasuries were weak and offered no support. The long bond was down 4/32 to yield 6.87 percent.
Barthel said the possibility of the Democrats regaining control of one or both houses of Congress was starting to resonate on Wall Street, and the reaction was jittery.

"Wall Street likes Clinton with a Republican Congress," Barthel said. "A Democratic Congress could mean less curtailment of entitlements and less fiscal restraint, something the bond and stock markets do not like."
The six-year-old rally picked up steam in November 1994 after Republican majorities took control of the House and Senate.

Barthel sees no specific catalyst for today's sell-off. Analysts say the market is overextended on the upside, and they question whether the earnings momentum needed to keep it going can be sustained.

"We are up almost 13 percent in 65 trading days. Put a pencil to that and you can make the case that the market got full very quickly, and that calls for a normal consolidation," Barthel said. "I wouldn't rule out a visit to Dow 5800."
Michael Metz, chief investment strategist at Oppenheimer & Co, said there was a "mini-stampede" to get out of stocks because of fear that earnings could not keep up momentum.
"What do you do for an encore?" he asked. "We are way overextended on the upside. Valuations are very rich. From here on in, it will be more difficult to maintain these near-record profit margins."
While the Dow Industrials fell, the laggard Dow Transportation Average rallied in what analysts said was an aberration due to strength in one stock, Conrail Inc.

Conrail, the second most active stock on the NYSE, was up 12-1/8 at 96-5/8, driven by Norfolk Southern Corp's $100 per share takeover offer. The bid is intended to derail CSX Corp's $92.50 per share merger pact with Conrail.
Norfolk fell 7/8 to 93-5/8. CSX was off 1/4 at 46.
The Dow Transportation Average was up 32 points, or 1.48 percent, at 2155.

The most actively traded stock on the NYSE was AT&T Corp, down 1-3/4 at 38-1/8. The company named R.R. Donnelley & Sons Co chairman John R. Walter to the position of president and chief operating officer. A spokesman said that Walter would replace Robert Allen as AT&T's chief executive in January 1998 and chairman later that year.
Shares of Netscape Communications Corp rallied 2-1/8 to 46-5/8 after reporting on Tuesday a quadrupling of quarterly earnings from the year-ago period.
-- Wall Street desk 212-859-1737
